text: Hi <@U02CALZ1EV9> - just got back from being ooo. Can you please share your hubid of the production account that you're working out of so I can have a look? Thanks so much for the nudge btw

Thank you Colby!

So I just checked and your hubid: 1687417 doesn't have sales or service hub enterprise, which is why you're not able to create a development sandbox.
CRM development tools (including dev sandboxes) are available to portals with either sales Enterprise or service hub enterprise
Ok, that makes sense. I was hoping CMS enterprise included the dev sandboxes as well. I should be able to use the standard sandbox for what I need.
I do have access to the CRM Development tools.
I assume that is because I am enrolled in the private JS building blocks beta.
Anyways, thanks for looking into it for me. I'll see if I can make do with the standard sandbox for now.
Interesting, thanks for sharing all of this Colby. Can you let me know what you're trying to work on for which originally you would have liked a development sandbox pls?
I am trying to set up a sandbox for my engineering team to use as a staging environment for the applications hosted on our site.
Thank you Colby, the Standard Sandbox should help with that. Can you tell me however if having access to a development sandbox would have helped you better and why?

I honestly don't understand the difference between the standard and dev sandboxes, other than the standard sandbox can be set up through our portal UI and the dev sandbox requires the CLI for setup. Do they function the same?
As long as the standard sandbox can support serverless functions and I can access it with the CLI, I think I will have what I need to setup our staging environment.

Thanks for the feedback.

You're right:
• today Standard Sandboxes can be created either through the UI or using the CLI
    ◦ Dev sandboxes can only be created using the CLI. 
The creation logic for dev sandboxes is to ensure that technical users are able to have their own isolated sandbox for when the job to be done requires them to have an isolated replica of the production account and when they want to do testing that could impact other testers active in a standard sandbox.

Some other noteworthy differences are:
• Today *`standard sandboxes`* are available to all customers who have at least one Enterprise level hub (CMS, Marketing, Sales, Service, Ops)
    ◦ *`Dev Sandboxes`* are part of the CRM Development Tools beta which is currently only available to Sales and/or Service Hub Enterprise customers. 
• *`Standard Sandboxes`* support syncing of the the same production account's features and functionalities, crm object definitions + custom objects, and all assets appearing in the screenshot.  
    ◦ *`Dev Sandboxes`* are bare-bones, only syncing production account's features and functionalities + production account's crm object definitions + custom objects. 
> As long as the standard sandbox can support serverless functions and I can access it with the CLI, I think I will have what I need to setup our staging environment.
Yes, you should be able to.

Hope this helps clarify some of the nuances, but let me know if you have any other questions, or feedback!!
:wave: is this with the React Beta?
That is very helpful! Thank you, <@U03MPE6V73M>. I think the Standard sandbox should allow me to do everything I need. I appreciate extra info.

With pleasure! If any feedback occurs to you as you're working through things, please don't hesitate to let me know. Also always open for a chat related to sandboxes, you can use <https://HubSpot.com/meetings/dthijzen/standard-sandboxes-feedback|my calendar link> if there's an opportunity :)
I truly appreciate it. I'll let you know if I have any questions along the way.
